reviewText: I can't tell you what the movie is about because the audio is very bad.  I turned the volume up all the way and it still wouldn't be understandable.  :(  I love Myrna Loy in movies and was looking forward to seeing her in her first starring role. The visual quality was lacking, but it was watchable if only I could hear actual dialog.
summary: I couldn't hear the dialogue - very muddy
Title: Indecent

reviewText: This is a movie from the 30's and it is precode.  Myrna Loy is great as usual and the movie is filmed in black and white.
Title: Indecent

reviewText: While I enjoyed stepping back in time and seeing the sights of a bygone era, the movie's story and its cautionary tale on manipulative women was slightly flat.
Title: Indecent

reviewText: Evidently MGM lent Myrna Loy out to one of the Poverty Row studios for this adaptation of "Vanity Fair". The production values are not great - quite a contrast to the extravagant Technicolor "Becky Sharp" of a few years later. Loy is fun to watch and the movie is definitely pre-code enjoyable. (Early in her career Loy was no goody-goody. Check her out as Fu-Manchu's daughter in "Mask of Fu-Manchu".) None of the film or TV adaptations of "Vanity Fair" that I have seen really does justice to the novel. However, the film is effective and worth a look. The streaming print is watchable with some infrequent sound problems.
Title: Indecent

reviewText: Do not buy! THIS VERSION IS A DVD-R MADE TO ORDER. I don't know why Amazon sells this when "Indecent" is  just another working title for the very same 1932 Pre-code film "Vanity Fair" starring Myrna Loy.This film is still in print and available on dvd for $7.98.Vanity Fair (1932)The  film is directed by Chester M. Franklin based on the novel by William Makepeace Thackeray. This is one of the Pre-code's that is an absolute joy to watch full of wicked amoral behavior & plunging  necklines.Loy's Becky is much nastier than Miriam Hopkins' version 3 years later inBecky Sharp. Easily you can imagine Jean Harlow or Clara Bow in this role, not the future MGM's Miss Goody Two Shoes; which  is who Myrna Loy became. Yes, before Myrna  Loy became MGM's Miss Perfect Sweetness America - she was actually  an actress!!; which makes her "Vanity Fair" & "Emma" MUST-SEES!VANITY FAIR was Loy's follow-up film to EMMA, in which she played a bratty and greedy daughter who almost destroys the loyal housekeeper (played by Marie Dressler).What makes Loy's fallen character so tragic is that she's supposed to be "genteel". Loy is the focus of all scenes & she has many outstanding/memorable scenes, such as the gambling scene in the casino where she tries to steal another woman's winning roulette bet! The more Loy's Becky loses her morality, the more beautiful she gets until she is finally "caught." Watch out for a rather shocking ending.Myrna Loy is absolutely stunning and gives a very solid performance. If you are at all a Myrna Loy fan; you can't miss out on :Vanity Fair (1932)!
summary: DO NOT BUY THIS VERSION - see review for link
Title: Indecent

reviewText: The dialogue and the direction does not present the book and the author in a way that justifies this screenplay.
Title: Indecent
